messageBody:
> > A question for the list: How do you organize your tests,
> particularly
> > if you write tests that are of both the functional scenario and
> single
> > object unit test varieties? The common approach seems to be to
> gather
> > all the tests for a given class in one test class.
> What about the
> > scenario type of tests? Organized by use case? What
> communicates
> > better, especially if we want to use the tests as documentation?
> >
>
> Usually I organize functional tests by subsystem/useCase.
>
> Regards,
>
> David
I think the organization depends on your browsing capabilities (i.e. using
an IDE or not, what IDE you are using, etc.) mainly because if it isn't too
cumbersome to break the tests out of production code locations, go ahead and
do it. I use VAJ for all of my Java development (at home and at work).
Because of VAJ's extremely easy-to-use browser, I never mix tests with
production code.

If I have com.foobar.parsers.xyz I would have a unit test package that maps
one-to-one: com.foobar.parsers.xyz.tests. If there are functional tests to
go with these classes they would be in
com.foobar.parsers.xyz.functionaltests.

We have actually split things up a little more where I work for the sake off
time-to-run-tests. If there are tests that are functional in nature but
take more than 50 - 60 seconds to run we put them in
com.foobar.parsers.xyz.quickfunctionaltests whereas the longer (most likely
full system) tests would be in the aforementioned
com.foobar.parsers.xyz.functionaltests.

-Jason
